intro: Phlomoides septentrionalis, commonly known as northern phlomoides, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Lamiaceae family, which includes many aromatic herbs and shrubs. The plant typically grows in open habitats such as prairies and dry woodlands, preferring well-drained soils. Its flowering period occurs in late spring to early summer, producing small, tubular flowers that are often violet or blue in color. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it is often found in disturbed or sandy soils.
